results.title: OpenAI introduces new tools to fast-track building of AI voice assistants
creator: Arsheeya Bajwa
results.description: OpenAI introduces new tools to fast-track building of AI voice assistants.
results.content: Oct 1 (Reuters) - OpenAI unveiled a host of new tools on Tuesday that would make it easier for developers to build applications based on its artificial intelligence technology, as the ChatGPT maker wrestles with tech giants to keep up in the generative AI race. The Microsoft-backed (MSFT.O) startup said a new real-time tool, rolling out immediately for testing, would allow developers to create AI voice applications using a single set of instructions. The process earlier required developers to go through at least three steps: first transcribing audio, then running the generated-text model to come up with an answer to the query and finally using a separate text-to-speech model. A large chunk of OpenAI's revenue comes from businesses that use its services to build their own AI applications, making the rollout of advanced capabilities a key selling point. Competition has also been heating up as technology giants, including Google-parent Alphabet (GOOGL.O), integrate AI models capable of crunching different forms of information such as video, audio, and text across their businesses. OpenAI expects its revenue to jump to $11.6 billion next year from an estimated $3.7 billion in 2024, Reuters reported last month. The company is also in the middle of a $6.5 billion fundraise that could value it at $150 billion. As part of Tuesday's rollout, OpenAI introduced a fine-tuning tool for models after training that would allow developers to improve the responses generated by models using images and text. This fine-tuning process can include feedback from humans who feed the model examples of good and bad answers based on its responses. Using images to fine-tune models would give them stronger image understanding capabilities, enabling applications such as enhanced visual search and improved object detection for autonomous vehicles, OpenAI said. The startup also unveiled a tool that would allow smaller models to learn from larger ones, along with 'Prompt Caching' that cuts some development costs by half by reusing pieces of the text AI has previously processed.

results.title: Microsoft: 'ever present' AI assistants are coming
creator: Zoe Kleinman
results.description: Microsoft is developing AI assistants with long-term memory that are expected to become integral co-pilots in daily life.
results.content: According to Microsoft’s AI head, Mustafa Suleyman, AI assistants with strong long-term memory capabilities are about a year away. These assistants could recall conversations and tasks, offering continuous help in daily activities. However, privacy and security concerns are rising regarding such deep integration into users’ lives. Microsoft’s CoPilot additions, like AI tools for news digest and voice assistance, continue expanding.

results.title: The Best Early Prime Day Deals on Asus Laptops, Desktops, and More
creator: K. Thor Jensen
results.description: PCMag reveals early Prime Day deals on Asus laptops, desktops, and more, featuring significant discounts on select products.
results.content: Asus deals during Amazon Prime Big Deal Days include discounts on laptops, desktops, and peripherals. For example, the Asus Vivobook is available for $799.99, a $179 discount. The ROG Strix Scar 18 Gaming Laptop offers a $540 discount at $3,359. Various other products, including Asus keyboards and mini PCs, are also part of the early deals.

results.title: Parents Can Now Set Time Limit Controls for Fortnite Gameplay
creator: Jibin Joseph
results.description: Epic Games has introduced a feature that allows parents to set time limits on Fortnite gameplay, offering more control over their child’s gaming time.
results.content: Parents can now set specific time limits and daily hours for Fortnite gameplay. Notifications alert kids 30 minutes before time ends, and parents can monitor gaming activity through Time Reports. Kids can also request time extensions, which parents can approve via email.

results.title: Equinix Signs $1.5 Billion Joint Venture to Build U.S. Data Center Infrastructure
creator: Reuters
results.description: Equinix has signed a $1.5 billion joint venture to develop U.S. data center infrastructure, expanding its reach and capacity in a growing market.
results.content: Equinix has entered into a $1.5 billion joint venture aimed at enhancing U.S. data center infrastructure. The collaboration is designed to bolster the company’s position as a leader in global data centers, offering expanded infrastructure to support the surge in data storage and cloud services across various industries.

results.title: Foxconn says execs from Nvidia, Google, BMW will speak at its annual forum
creator: Reuters
results.description: Foxconn announced that executives from Nvidia, Google, and BMW will speak at its annual tech day forum.
results.content: Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics maker, will host its annual forum featuring executives from Nvidia, Google, and BMW discussing AI, electric vehicles, and digital health. Foxconn also plans to unveil two new electric vehicle models at the event.

results.title: Microsoft's AI Copilot makeover lets it see and speak
creator: Eric Hal Schwartz
results.description: Microsoft has updated its Copilot AI with new voice and vision features, making it more interactive and helpful in everyday tasks.
results.content: Microsoft's Copilot AI now includes voice and vision capabilities. Users can engage vocally with the AI, while the Copilot Vision feature lets it analyze what's on screen. These updates make the AI more dynamic, adapting to user preferences and enhancing productivity tools like image editing. The new features are available across web, mobile, and Windows apps.

results.title: Epic Games sues Google and Samsung over phone settings, accusing them of violating antitrust laws
creator: Sarah Parvini
results.description: Epic Games has filed a lawsuit against Google and Samsung, accusing them of blocking third-party app competition on Samsung devices with the 'Auto Blocker' feature.
results.content: Epic Games sued Google and Samsung, accusing them of anti-competitive practices with Samsung's 'Auto Blocker' feature, which limits app installations to authorized sources like the Galaxy Store and Google Play. Epic claims this entrenches Google’s dominance and undermines competition in Android app distribution. Samsung says users can disable the feature and denies the claims.

results.title: Can AI make video games more immersive? Some studios turn to AI-fueled NPCs for more interaction
creator: Sarah Parvini
results.description: Game studios are using generative AI to enhance NPC interactions, providing dynamic and immersive experiences in video games.
results.content: Game studios are increasingly leveraging AI to make non-player characters (NPCs) more interactive and spontaneous. Generative AI allows for more dynamic conversations and player interactions. Studios like Jam & Tea and technology like Nvidia’s ACE platform are leading the way, but ethical concerns remain.

results.title: The AI boom may give Three Mile Island a new life supplying power to Microsoft’s data centers
creator: Marc Levy
Matt O’Brien
results.description: The owner of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant plans to restart its reactor to supply power to Microsoft’s data centers under a 20-year agreement.
results.content: Constellation Energy plans to restart Three Mile Island's Unit 1 under a 20-year agreement with Microsoft, providing carbon-free power to its data centers. The move reflects a broader trend of using nuclear power to address increasing energy demands, especially from data centers and AI operations.
